See, once four warning Elements, embrace.

div.stage: Thunder and Lightning.— Enter five or six like Devils; Water and Earth are let down to the middle with two Devils— Fire and Air, are carried up half way into the Air, with two Devils—

sp.speaker: Sir G. Gaz. Noddy.
sp.p: Help, help, help; Murder— Murder—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Widow, for Heav'ns sake, intercede for us to the Devils—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Oh law, what will my Mother and Sister say, when they hear I am carried away by the Devil—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Who are ye, discover your selves then?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: By Charles's Wain, don't you know me?

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Why look you, d'ye see, it is I, it is I—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
My old Suiters, we are all oblig'd to you, my Masters, you have taken great pains to make your selves Ridiculous—
— ha,— ha,— Pray Sir release 'em for my sake—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: You may Command, Madam, let 'em down there—

sp.speaker: All Suit.
sp.p: Thanks good Widow.

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Whe faith since we were to lose you, Madam, we thought losers might have leave to speak, and therefore by offering our Service to this Gentleman, we got this opportunity to speak a little of our minds to you—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: And I think we have pretty freely, and at our own Costs too; for I owe Money for some of the Painting— but the Planets are sufficient to pay the Painter—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: If ever I court Widow again for your sake, may I be made a Pissing-post of; well, I find Widows are confounded insupportable witty Devils.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: We are all oblig'd to you, Sir, for this discovery.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: My shame, Madam, urg'd me to contrive some way to discover the Authors of my disgrace— But, Madam, to divert you I have brought a Servant of mine to entertain you with a Dance—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I am indebted to you for this favour, Sir— Please Gentlemen to walk in and partake of a small Collation, and then, my Dear, we will retire to surfeit on Loves sweets—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We follow you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Curse on ill luck! What a Devil should be become of this Sister of mine, had she not promised to get the Widow for me, I had not slipt the opportunity which now is irrecoverably lost, she's Married! now the Pox or Impotence be his Curse, for I cannot with patience see my self thus chous't— ha— here comes my brisk Bridegroom— good, I have thought on an excellent way, if possible, to retrieve her— I'le wheadle him to drink, make him damnably drunk, so consequently impotent, and a Widow disappointed, turns Devil, will sue a divorce, and then she's mine.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Oh Sir, most opportunely met— are you alone?—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Yes, Sir,— Your Pleasure—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I am come to— cut your Throat.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: How Sir!— cut my Throat, you'l give me a reason, Sir, for it, I hope—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I saw what amorous glances past between my Wife and you at Dinner, and since too I have discovered that which has rais'd such a Storm within me, that nothing but thy death can restore my former calmness—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Jealous by this light— I hope he has not met with my Letter I convey'd to the Widow— [Aside. Heav'ns Sir, what jealous on the first night!

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I am all rage with jealousie, your Letter, Sir— see there the reason, Villain, and then judg if I can pardon such an injury— Therefore prepare to yield up either Life, or Love—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, since you have discovered my passion, then know I do, must, and will love your Widow, nay, dote upon the sight of her, and yet no harm to you, since you possess the wealth, you cannot barr a longing stander by, to wish and sigh, since you know 'tis in vain; therefore I will persist— ah 'tis a charming Creature!

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Hell and Furies! shall I stand tamely still, and hear a fellow boldly to my face proclaim my Infamy!

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: A fellow, Sir▪ Provoke me not, I say provoke me not; if you do, by Heav'n, if possible, I'le cuckol'd thee before thy face—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: This is beyond all patience, base Villain draw—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Pish Sir, your little Bodkin frights not me, see I have one can match it— Yet I believe thee Valiant, or such a little whipper-ginnie durst not have been so desperate to have ventur'd on a longing Widow—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: How, Sir, have at thy heart!—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Good Child, thou art too forward,— reserve thy vigour for another place, it will be little enough, I'le engage— for young, Sir, there can be no comparison between you and I, in love affairs—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: How mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: You may perhaps be well enough for the Theory, to cringe, and whine, and wheadle your self into a Virgins heart; but a Widows wise discerning Eye must of necessity read here the only man that's fittest for the Practick part—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Heav'ns! Do but hereafter look upon her with one pleasing glance, and I'le damn thy Soul.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: A Bully in Swadling-clouts by this light, 'tis the youngest Hector I ever met with in my life— a gad, little Squire, were she the great Turk's favourite, I'de look and gaze altho I knew my death should follow, and let me tell thee, had somebody been true to their promise, your fortune had been mine— therefore, little one, you may thank my cross Stars for your good success. A Pox on an absent Sister—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: How Sir, oblig'd to you? Oh insupportable! thou base detracter of my honour, who not only would supplant my love, but blast my reputation, and make me undeserving of a Ladies favour.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: If you come to that point, Sir, what can you boast of, should be so attractive? I must confess thou appearest a hopeful Stripling, and I question not you have the pretty impertinents of one of your Age, as Dancing, Singing, affected Gestures, be peirtly witty, making bold with every new Play comes out, and extravagantly tawdrey in every new fashion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Death and the Devil!

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: These accomplishments, I must confess, may be very surprizing to a poor young thing of a Boarding-School, who never had love made to her but by her Dancing-Master, or some such follow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: This is beyond all sufferance—

div.stage: [Strives to run at him, he Parryes.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p:
This won't do— and now, little one, I le discharge my Conscience, between you and I, I do verily believe, the Widow that was, and your Wife that is, Married you only for a Drudg or Steward of her Estate, while she spends it on pleasures, with such vigorous Blades as my self, and who knows it may be my turn; which if it be, faith
I'le be very reasonable, and Cuckold thee as seldom as possibly I can—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I'le hear no more; but thus will make a passage to thy Soul, for I swear thy Ruine, Death, Damnation—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Say you so, then 'tis time to look about— and since you provide me, little one, know this, that if I kill thee, I swear to marry the Widow the next day—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Thus I prevent thy boasting— dull, dull, Brother, not know your own flesh and blood. Nob. makes up to her with his Sword, Mrs. H. discovers her self.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: My Sister▪ I'm all amazement▪

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Now Sir, what think you of my design?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Design quotha! 'twas well you discovered your self, or I had spoil'd all;— but I'm a Dog if I understand what you mean?— you are Married—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I am to the Widow, I knew not how to cheat the Parson; but I question not, but to deceive the Widow e're I sleep—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: As how, as how?— I long to hear—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: See, my Husband comes with some intelligence—.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Is that my Brother Hadland?—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Sir, My Lady is retir'd to her Chamber—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Leave off your distance now, sweet heart; for I have told my Brother all.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Kind-Brother I obliging Sister!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: But Brother, do you like my Widow in earnest?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Like her! Heavn's! I love her infinitely! were she not Mistress of a farthing, agad, I believe I should have Married her, there's such an aiery sweetness in her face—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Say you so, then along with me, I have one design more, and if that take, we are once more happy—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Lead on whil'st I follow, and admire thy wit.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: T Thus far I am prosperous, Widow, I have not done with you yet; I have wheadled all her Keys out of her Custody, and in her Closet I found the Writing of my Estate, thou dear, dear Parchment, how I am over-joy'd to hug thee in my Arms once more— the Widow comes—

div.stage: Enter Widow, undress'd in a Night-Gown.
div.p: My life, my Soul, my only joys on Earth, haste, haste to Bed, that I may be compleatly bless'd with an Heav'n of Pleasures and delight.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh let me embrace the mighty Treasure I have this day gain'd!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Delay not the Consummation of our bliss, to bed, to bed, my dear, and there we'l surfeit with delights unspeakable.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I go, but prithee stay not long behind—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I'le but to my appartment, and undress, then fly to rifle all thy Charms— now, Widow, thou art safe—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Kind Rogue, I am— I cannot avoid laughing to think how surpriz'd the Widow will be, well Girl, I'le endeavour to behave my self so, that she shall have no reason to complain, nor you to repent the trick you have put upon her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Do that, and I am well pleas'd, I believe I am the first Bridegroom that ever procur'd for his Bride the first Night.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: The obliging'st in the world, and the kindest Sister too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Away then— be brisk, and disgrace me not.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Dear, honest, kind, obliging, witty Rogue, adieu— now for the Widow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.l: Widow, y'are caught at last—
Thy Husband's subtleties shall be repaid,
Thus Women are by Women best betray'd.

div.head: SCENE the Second. The Hall.
div.stage: Sir O. Santloe, Sanders, Gazer, Noddy— Sam. Drinking at a Table.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Well done, my friends, put it briskly about— now the Bride and Bridegroom are preparing for bed, let us Drink their healths— Sam. give me a Glass— Son Sanders, top and bottom to you—

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: I'le do you reason, Sir— Mr. Santloe, the Bride and Bridegrooms healths.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Mr. Gazer—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: I'le Pledg you, Sir, tho by Aries the Sign is in the Head with me already, Mr. Noddy have at you—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let it come, hang Sorrow, it must be drown'd, I find—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Sir, I'le not bate you an ace of top and bottom, off with it, off with it for shame, I say again, top and bottom is my word—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Lay aside Indignation, Sir, I'le do't, tho I dye for't, but yfeck I have so topt and bottom'd it already, I can hardly breath—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Hye, that's he, that's he— What, Son Peter, no frollick, no frollick, Sirrah Boy, be merry, or I'le dis-inherit thee— Ah, when I was of your Age, and at the Temple, I was the Cock of all the Jovial Blades in Town— I was always the Captain of a Temple-Rebellion, broke Benchers heads with the Temple pots most dexterously, lye with my Laundress, got her with Bastard, and made her lay it at a Benchen's door, by Gogmagog—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: So, so, all will out— now shall I have pious instructions to follow the Example of a sober Father—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: I have beat Watches, have had my head broke, and been in the Compter so often, that it cost your Grandfather above a Hundred pounds one year to cure my broken head, and to ransom me from Limbo— and yet you see, Sirrah, I am a sober discreet man now—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Wondrous discreet thus to display your weakness—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Son Sanders, what ne'r a Song in Budget— by Gogmagog, this whoring Age has spoil'd all good harmless mirth and Company— All the young fellows now a days single out their Does, and retire as if it were nothing but rutting time with 'em— but in my Days we should not have sat half so long without a Catch or two, and top and bottom going briskly about yfaith—

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: Prithee let's have the Song, you made the last drinking bout, and one glass more will lay your Father to rest—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: I have a Song, Sir, which if you please well sing— but all must joyn in the Chorus.—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Yes marry shall they, Sir— and so will I— but first let every one take top and bottom in his hand—

lg.l: COme troul it away,
We'll drink up the day,
Let none from his standing retire,
We'l Laugh, Drink, and Sing,
And Bacchus's Spring
We'l drain, and our prowess admire.
Cho. We'l Laugh, &c.
Old Age we despise
Whilst Wine we can prize,
And briskly can take off our Glasses;
Wine, life does repair,
And banishes Care,
But Temp'rance wou'd make us all Asses.
Cho. Wine, life, &c.
Let the Pollitick fool
Live dully by Rule,
While our Wits we refine in our Liquor,
My Soul's in that Wine
Which puts the Divine
To a Nonplus, and turns up the Viccar.
Cho. My Soul's, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Well done yfaith my Lads— and now off with top and bottom— [All Drink. ho, ho, ho Boys, Peter I'le give thee an Hundred pounds a year more for this Boy—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Say, and hold Sir, that you have often done in your Glasses; but has forbid the banes when sober—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Oh the sweet days of Youth— I have roar'd it in my time yfaith— and so topt and bottom'd it, that by Gogmagog we have all bin top heavy before we have parted— Now Son Peter, ne'r a Jig or Horn-pipe about you? how has my Money bin spent at Dancing-School, I pray?—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: He would make me as ridiculous as himself— [Aside. Those Dances are quite out of fashion, Sir, and Genteiler are now in Mode, Sarabands, Minuets Entries, and the like—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Pox on your hard nam'd Dances and Wine too, they never prove good, nor wholsom— but Sirrah, to convince you, nothing can be finer than a Lancashire Horn-pipe— Fidlers strike up—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: I Vow, Sir, 'tis in supportably admirable—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Before I left the Temple, I was the only Reveller as old as I was; I cou'd have footed the Measures, and Danc't Horn-pipes with e're a young fellow of 'em all. Sam, Give me top and bottom— Mr. Noddy, my Service to you—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Yfeck I'le pledg you—

lg.l: Is not John Sanders dead? [Sir O. Sings.
And is not his Wife a Whore?
For she will go drunk to bed,
And yet she'l have one Pot more?
Our Cat is to be hang'd,
And all to be tumbl'd i'th' mire,
For scratching my Wifes Huquissin,
As she sat by the Fire.—

div.p: Ah, when I was young, I had a thousand such frollicks as these, off with your Liquor man, off with it, I say.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Top and bottom, as you say, Sir Oliver, yfecks—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: So ho, my Boys, who says I am old, see there my conquest over Youth— this Whoring weakens 'em so, they are not able to take of a chirping Cup or two now adays—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Now Sam, thy frollick?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What grinding of Knives Sir? have at it then— Knives to Grind, Knives to Grind—

div.stage: Takes off his Perriwig, and runs a Chair before him, like a Wheel-barrow.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: How now Sam, what art thou frollicking too—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A Well-willer to mirth Sir, and now you shall see me grind Knives as dexterously with a Chair, as the Fellows in the Street with a Grind-stone—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Well done my Lad— Here's something to encourage thee—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What's here, a Newgate Groat, by this Light he's short lived, he is so confounded liberal— ah Sir, this is nothing; I can tumble with any Bartholomew Fellow, Run up a Wall like a Cat; but I can act a Breast of Mutton so naturally, that our Cook-Maid the other night had like to have spitted me for one, I did it so to the life—

div.stage: Enter Sir Gregory Lovemuch, beaten in by a Maid with a Spit—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold, Murder, Murder—

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Out you old Leacher, invade my Honour?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Laugh.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Wats the matter, Sir Gregory?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p:
I only desir'd a kindness or so, being set agog with
the Widows Marriage, and the Baggage had not only the incivility to deny me; but has most unmercifully chastis'd me too.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: By Gogmagog well enough served, for leaving top and bottom— and old Letchery will be catteryauling, tho they are sure to come by the worst.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: For Heav'ns sake, Gentlemen, come to the Bride-Chamber, some accident or other has hapned; for the Bride cryes out, and seems by her Speech to be in some strange confusion.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: It's nothing but her being coy, and yfaith the young Bridegroom seems a man of Mettle, and will put her to't, I'le warrant.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What should this mean?

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Let us go see, I fear my young Blade's too brisk for her— gently, gently good Youngster, be not so boysterous— [Shreiks again. Again, what a stubborn Baggage 'tis— on my lise he is ravishing her— let us in and see Gentlemen—

div.head: SCENE the Last.
The Widow discovered sitting on a Bed in a Night-Gown, Noble in Bed, holding her by the Gown.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Heav'n protect me! Villain unhand me—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: I say, Widow come to Bed, or I shall grow very angry; for I'm impatient, and will not be delay'd any longer.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Guard me, ye Powers above! Protect my honour, or I'm lost for ever should my Husband come—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p:
Whose fault will that be; therefore be speedy, let me antedate my young Squire, and I'le be gone— Nay, no struggling, but yield quietly— I need not a resistance, for I am all on flame already— not yet? agad persist in stubbornness, and I'le publish it in all places that I have layn
with thee, no matter whether it be truth or no— and then Lady bright, that trifling title Honour, must be surrender'd; but be kind, and I shall be all silence and obedience—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I'le rather dye, than yield—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Say you so? Then I find I must try strength.

div.stage: They strive, she gets from him— is going out of the Door. Enter Mrs. Hadland meets her.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ha! my Husband!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: What coming for me Widow? This was kindly done— let us to Bed, for now I am ready to perform the Rites of Love.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What shall I do? undone, for ever wretched—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: What means this strange Confusion!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Alass, Sir, I'm not well— I was just going to call up my Maid, for some Cordial— Tis but too true, for my Spirits fail me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Such vain excuses belong to Virgin Modesty, but Widows should know better— then, lay aside this veil, and meet my love with equal flames, that both may be transported into Extasies—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: For ever I am ruin'd—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Sure y'are the first Widow ever fear'd th' imbraces of a second Husband— Come, come tremble not— but to Bed.

div.stage: [Leads her to the Bed, opens the Curtain, discovers Noble standing in a Night-Gown upon the Bed—
div.p: Ha! Noble here— Hell and the Devil!
Base perfidious Woman, now I see the cause of your disorders, was your Lust so hot you could not stay till the first Night was past?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Good Sir, hear me—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: May'st thou be for ever dumb, or I deaf, rather than lend an Ear to thy bewitching tongue— Now Sir, how durst you attempt the dishonouring of my Bed? Do you laugh? I shall spoil your mirth—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Who can forbear at such an Idle question— rather Sir, how durst you Marry, and fondly think to preserve such a tempting Creature entirely for your self,— Sir, where I love, I dare do any thing to enjoy; and a Pox on your officious hast and jealousie, had you but stayed two minutes longer, your business had been done, and you ne'r the wiser—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Confusion! This to my face?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Yes, faith Sir, 'twas most uncivilly done, and very unlike a Husband to intrude; but I pardon you for once, for I hope in time you will understand better—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Base Villain! Did I for this cast a friends Arms about thee? gave thee the welcom of a man of Honour? and is this your return of gratitude? Hence, begon, and take that Volume of corrupted Beauty; for henceforth shesh I be to me like the Book of Fate, for ever claspt.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Wretched Woman, was this the promis'd blessing of an indulgent Husband! Speak Sir, and clear my Honour, how you got here; for Heav'n be my Witness, I was as great a stranger to his being here, as you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: In vain are idle words, out of my doors, for ever I discard you from my house—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I find too late your drift, my Wealth (Curse on it) was the Original of your design, take it to save my Honour; and what is't I would not give to be rid of so base a fellow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I thank you for my own, sweet Lady— but I scorn to be out done in courtesie— therefore in return, make you this present— provided you'l confirm you Estate on me—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I will— what laugh you at my misery—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Faith Widow, you are caught; for know, I am already Married to another—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How Married to another! I am all astonishment: Villain, how durst you attempt so desperate an act; an act by which your life is forfeited? and question not, but I'le have full revenge for this affront y'ave offer'd me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Rail on, 'tis Musick in my Ears, but faith you are not like to stir till we are friends—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What's your design? who are you—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p:
Come, come, no more questions, my design was
only to provide a Husband for thee— how say you to my Friend here, methinks he would make an able Husband for a Widow.

sp.speaker: Within. Sir O.
sp.p: So ho, Mr. Bridegroom open the Door, and let Sack-posset enter—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: How say you, Widow, is it a match— or they all enter, and I'le forswear all I have said, and make you infamous to the world—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: And faith so will I, Widow— if you consent not.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hold, hold Gentlemen— What shall I do? my Honour this way will be lost— Leave me to my own choice, you know not what then I may do—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: All one for that, Widow, so it must be—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Or Egad they come— see I am ready to unlock, is it a Bargain?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Take half my Estate, my House, Goods, any thing, rather than force me to so rash an Act—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: How rash! to Marry an able fellow! this is an affront, I cannot put up; therefore thus I revenge my self—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hold, hold Sir, let me consider but one Minute—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: I'le give thee a looking and a thinking time, that is but fair; for I am certain the more you view me and consider, the more you'l like me—

sp.speaker: Within. Sir O.
sp.p: On my Conscience they are reconcil'd, done their business, and fairly turn'd to sleep.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Now, Madam, what is it you resolve?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Not to consent—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Egad they come then—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hold, what are you?—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: No questions, for Conscience sake—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I yield, I yield—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Swear then—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: By all that's good, I will be yours—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Seal it—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Gentlemen, pray enter—

div.stage: Enter Sir O. Santloe, P. Santloe, Mr. Sanders, Lady Santloe, Clarina, Eugenia, Sir G. Lovemuch, Gazer, Noddy, Attendants. Mr. Hadland without Disguise—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: What's here, two Bridegrooms? I'le warrant her crying out, was, for want of the Second—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Gentlemen, bear witness, I here discharge the Widow, from her Marriage with me.—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: How, parting before ye have bedded? what's the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Some private Reasons, Sir Oliver, which more at leisure you shall know—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Before these Gentlemen, I take him for my Husband.

sp.speaker: Sir G. L. Gaz. Noddy.
sp.p: The Devil give you Joy then—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: See here the transformation— and Widow in a young huffing Bully, see your Friend and Servant Eliz. Hadland—

div.stage: Mrs. H. and her Husband discover themselves.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: And Thomas Hadland, her Serving-man and Husband.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Am I out-witted by my Enemy then!

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: What a notable frollicking Woman is this! Is she the Bridegroom, and my worshipful Serving-man, are you there?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: A poor wrong'd Gentleman, Sir, willing to serve for his own—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Pox on her, was it she disgrac'd me at the Treat, I'le steal off before they take notice of me—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: By Capricorn, and so will I—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Look you, Madam, d'ye see, I have spent at least Forty Pounds in Cloaths, Coaches, Journeys and so forth, in Courting of you, and since you have chous'd me of your self, I expect satisfaction— which I will have if there be Law—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Take your course, Sir—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: So I will, by Jehosaphat—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Now Madam, no more your Enemy, but Sister; for I must call this Gentleman Brother.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Then my fortune's better than I could have expected,
since I am assured he is a Gentleman in all respects— and thus all animosities shall cease.—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Why, now the Bells they go trim, they go trim— Wife, with this Ladies leave, we'l make no more hours on't; for this is as fine a contracting time, we could have wisht for, and the Parson to morrow shall finish this Nights work, come to the Book, to the Book young men—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: 'Slid Sam, what's to be done now.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Your Friend and Servant knows no more than the post, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: How say you, Madam, is it a match between your Neice and my Son? do't, and I am resolv'd Mr. Sanders shall be my Son in Law—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I freely consent, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Mrs. Eugenia, your hand—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: But not my heart, for that is Mr. Sanders's—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But with your leave, Sir Oliver, I'le joyn 'em—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: With all my heart, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Mr. Sanders, take this Lady.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, blest be your goodness for this inestimable treasure.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Cuds boddykins, what means she?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Here Mr. Santloe, in a Sister find a wise—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Sure the Widow has dealt with the Devil, or else hath heard of our mutual love, and thus sooths our passions—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: By Gogmagog, the Widow's mad— my Son Marry his own Sister! what Riddle is this?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: One of Seventeen years standing, Sir— You remember my Sister Morly Nurs'd your Daughter, who at that time had a Daughter too—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: What of all this—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: My Sisters fortunes decaying, she gave you her Eugenia, and kept your Clarina with her self— afterwards fortune smiling on her Husband's industry, she on her Death-bed did reveal this secret, and wisht me when occasion served to make it known—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Hyeday the Town's our own agen—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, this is beyond all president, not to be equal'd— and now Sir, I may with confidence own I was this day Married to my supposed Sister.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: By Gogmagog, you were a desperate Boy; how could you tell but that it was your Sister in earnest?

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Nature was not so dull to let me languish for a Sister; for notwithstanding what my Mother said, yet love retain'd its native heat, and bad me still love on— Oh my blest Soul—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Daughter come into thy Father's arms, see, excess of Joy will make affection melt.

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.p: What tears have I bestow'd on a lost Daughter, yet left her behind me.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: This is beyond all thought surprizing— and now, Girl, since your wit has been the kind directer of my Fortunes, with my Widows leave here, freely command whatever's in my power—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I shall comply with you in everything.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I thank you for your obliging offer, and I shall desire nothing more, but the confirmation of that Portion which your rigorous Husband had deceiv'd my Father of, before he dyed—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Your generosity is so great I can deny you nothing— consult with your Lawyer, and I shall willingly subscribe to any thing you shall desire—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H. Mr. H.
sp.p: We are oblig'd to you—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Cudsboddy kins, this was a notable waggish trick, and by Gogmagog, much like a second Wedding, and I give you joy with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Madam, fear nothing; tho I have appear'd a wild Debauchee; yet you shall find an Indulgent Husband— and now, Gentlemen, let us in and congratulate each others good success and fortunes.

lg.l: Thus in the Storms of Fortune you may find,
Where Justice is deficient, Wit proves kind.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: KNowing too well, Gallants, your natural spight,
We bar your censuring priviledg to Night;
For your Diversion, this was ne'r design'd,
How can our Author then, expect you kind?
Your malice is so great to One unknown
That like the Play, or not, you cry him down,
Who is not one o'th' huffing Wits o'th' Town:
Nay, your ill natures bare so great a sway,
Often ye Damn, befor you've seen the Play;
Such Bully-Wits, like Butchers should not sit,
Nor be impannelled at the Bar of Wit;
There's such a Native Cruelty in them,
Without a Consultation they condemn.
Then to Vacation-Customers we sue,
We have our ends to Night, if we've pleas'd you;
Kind Sirs, let not the Criticks of the Town
Awe ye— But let your Judgments be your Own,
Consider well—
Here is no Satire on a Marry'd life,
Nor damn'd Lampoon upon the City-Wife;
No Cheats discover'd of the Man of Trade,
Nor who Gallants your Wives are here display'd,
Nor your own secret Pleasures too betray'd:
Then Judg the Play, unbyass'd may ye be,
And from the snarling Criticks set us free.
